message_1:
Calculate the change in enthalpy (ΔH) for the following reaction at 25°C given the standard enthalpies of formation for each compound: 

2H2(g) + O2(g) → 2H2O(g) 

Standard enthalpies of formation: 
ΔHf° (H2O)(g) = -241.82 kJ/mol
ΔHf° (H2)(g) = 0 kJ/mol
ΔHf° (O2)(g) = 0 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the change in enthalpy (ΔH) for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔH = Σ ΔHf° (products) - Σ ΔHf° (reactants)

For the given reaction:

2H2(g) + O2(g) → 2H2O(g)

The products are 2 moles of H2O(g), and the reactants are 2 moles of H2(g) and 1 mole of O2(g).

Using the standard enthalpies of formation provided:

ΔH = [2 × ΔHf° (H2O)(g)] - [2 × ΔHf° (H2)(g) + ΔHf° (O2)(g)]

ΔH = [2 × (-241.82 kJ/mol)] - [2 × (0 kJ/mol) + (0 kJ/mol)]

ΔH = (-483.64 kJ) - (0 kJ)

ΔH = -483.64 kJ

The change in enthalpy (ΔH) for the reaction is -483.64 kJ.
